message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the relationship between heat and the different phases of water. Heat causes water to turn into vapor through a process called evaporation. Option (A) is incorrect because condensation is the process of water vapor turning back into liquid. Option (B) is incorrect because melting is the process of solid water (ice) turning into liquid water. Option (D) is a play on words and not related to the phase changes of water.

This question requires basic knowledge about the phase changes of water. When heat is applied to water, it undergoes a process called evaporation, where it turns into vapor or steam. Option (A) is incorrect because condensation is the process by which water vapor turns back into liquid water, not the process by which water turns into vapor. Option (B) is incorrect because melting is the process by which a solid substance turns into a liquid, not the process by which water turns into vapor. Option (D) is a play on words and not related to the phase changes of water.

This question requires basic knowledge about the phase changes of water. When heat is applied to water, it causes it to turn into vapor through a process called evaporation. Condensation, mentioned in option (A), is the reverse process where water vapor turns back into liquid water. Option (B) is incorrect because heat does not cause water to melt, but rather it causes ice to melt into liquid water. Option (D) is not a valid process or term related to the phase changes of water.
